ui.notesDefault: Select a level to view tailored board follow-on actions.
ui.noRatingsMessage: Once all actions have a rating, this page can be exported as a board pack. Use the follow-on actions under each item to shape your forward plan and committee work programme.

sectors.generic: Use this model as a generic benchmark across strategy, risk, people, incident readiness and assurance.
sectors.financial: For financial services, pay particular attention to supplier risk (A4), resilience (D1–D2) and regulatory obligations (D3, E5).
sectors.health: For health and care, focus on protecting sensitive data (A1, A5), staff behaviours (C1–C4) and incident response (D1–D4).
sectors.public: For public sector, alignment with statutory duties and transparency is key – emphasise risk integration (A2), assurance (E4) and regulatory readiness (E5).
sectors.critical: For critical infrastructure, prioritise resilience of critical services (A1, D1–D2), supplier chains (A4) and board readiness (D3, E1–E2).

actions.title: Identify and prioritise critical technology, information and services
actions.notes: Gain assurance that the technology processes, information and services critical to the organisation's objectives have been identified, prioritised, and agreed.
levels: Board has no assurance that critical technology, information, or services are identified or prioritised.
Board receives informal assurance that some critical assets are known, but not documented or agreed.
Board is assured a documented list exists, but prioritisation and review are limited.
Board is assured critical assets are identified, prioritised, and reviewed periodically.
Board is assured the process is embedded, routinely updated, and aligned to business goals.
followOn: Ask management to confirm if a list of critical systems and data exists and how it is used.
Require a documented inventory of critical assets with owners and impact ratings; compare to actual operations.
Set minimum prioritisation criteria and require regular attestations that changes are captured.
Ensure the process links to organisational objectives and risk appetite; define triggers for out-of-cycle updates.
Maintain annual independent assurance over completeness and prioritisation; benchmark against peers.

actions.title: Senior ownership and integration of cyber security risks
actions.notes: Agree senior ownership of cyber security risks and gain assurance that they are integrated into the organisation’s wider enterprise risk management and internal controls.
levels: Board has no assurance of senior ownership or integration of cyber risks into enterprise risk management.
Ownership is informal and unclear, with weak links to organisation-wide risk processes.
A named senior owner exists; integration into organisation-wide risk management is partial.
Clear ownership and full integration into enterprise-wide risk management and internal controls.
Ownership and integration are embedded, reviewed regularly, and continuously improved.
followOn: Appoint a senior executive as Cyber Risk Owner and require inclusion of cyber risks in the main risk register.
Request a simple RACI for cyber governance and use consistent risk ratings across all risks.
Mandate risk-to-control mapping and consolidated indicators aligned to the board’s risk appetite.
Commission independent effectiveness reviews and require evidence that actions are resourced and tracked.
Maintain external benchmarking and continuous improvement plans; refresh thresholds and reporting expectations annually.

actions.title: Define and communicate cyber risk appetite
actions.notes: Define and clearly communicate the organisation’s cyber security risk appetite and gain assurance that the organisation has an action plan to meet these risk expectations.
levels: Board has no assurance that cyber risk appetite is defined or communicated.
Appetite is discussed informally but not documented or shared.
A documented appetite exists; supporting plan and metrics are limited.
Appetite is clear, communicated, and supported by an action plan.
Appetite and plans are embedded, reviewed, and adjusted proactively.
followOn: Request management to draft a simple cyber risk appetite statement and bring it to the board.
Require a documented appetite aligned to business objectives and a communication plan for senior leaders.
Set clear indicators and thresholds linked to appetite and require a funded, time-bound action plan.
Introduce scenario testing and link appetite to strategic changes; commission independent validation of reporting.
Refresh appetite annually using horizon scanning; ensure major decisions reference appetite explicitly.

actions.title: Manage supplier and supply-chain cyber risk
actions.notes: Gain assurance that supplier information is routinely assessed, proportionate to their level of risk and that the organisation is resilient to cyber security risks from its supply chain and business partners.
levels: Board has no assurance that supplier cyber risks are assessed or managed.
Some informal checks occur; approach is inconsistent and undocumented.
Documented assessments exist, but coverage and monitoring are limited.
Supplier risks are routinely assessed, proportionate to risk level, with resilience measures in place.
Supply-chain resilience is embedded, regularly reviewed, and tested.
followOn: Ask for a list of key suppliers and their current assurance status; require basic cyber clauses in contracts.
Mandate a supplier risk policy with tiering and standard due diligence for higher tiers.
Set minimum assurance levels per tier and require ongoing monitoring and sample reviews of high-risk suppliers.
Require contingency/exit plans and tests for critical suppliers; introduce board-level metrics.
Maintain independent assurance, run supplier compromise scenarios, and benchmark supplier governance against peers.

actions.title: Conduct regular cyber risk assessments and mitigations
actions.notes: Gain assurance that risk assessments are conducted regularly and that risk mitigations account for recent, or expected, changes in the organisation, technology, regulations or wider threat landscape.
levels: Board has no assurance that cyber risk assessments are conducted.
Assessments occur occasionally and informally; they ignore changes in the business and threat environment.
Documented assessments occur, but responsiveness and tracking of mitigations are limited.
Board is assured assessments are regular and account for changes in the organisation and wider threats.
Assessment and mitigation are embedded, proactive, and provide timely, decision-ready insight.
followOn: Require a risk assessment schedule and a plain-English method; ask for an initial summary of top risks.
Set triggers for out-of-cycle assessments and require documented change tracking linked to business/tech changes.
Mandate action logs with owners and deadlines, and require evidence that assessments use current threat information.
Introduce forward-looking analysis and link outcomes to investment planning and lessons learned.
Maintain independent validation of the method and data quality; refresh metrics and thresholds regularly.

actions.title: Develop and align a cyber strategy with organisational strategy
actions.notes: Gain assurance that the organisation has developed a cyber strategy and this is aligned with, and embedded within, the wider organisational strategy.
levels: Board has no assurance a cyber strategy exists or aligns to the business strategy.
A draft or informal cyber strategy exists; alignment and embedding are unclear.
A documented cyber strategy exists; partial alignment with the business and limited adoption.
Cyber strategy is aligned and embedded in planning, budgeting, and change processes.
Strategy is business-led, routinely refreshed, and supports competitive advantage.
followOn: Ask management to confirm whether a cyber strategy exists and request a short summary.
Require a board-approved strategy document with clear goals, timelines, and owners, based on stakeholder input.
Require mapping of cyber goals to business objectives, a communication plan, and evidence of adoption.
Introduce metrics tied to strategy outcomes and cross-functional governance with reporting to the board.
Schedule an annual strategic refresh and benchmark the strategy against peers and codes of practice.

actions.title: Align cyber strategy with risk appetite, regulation, and change
actions.notes: Gain assurance that the cyber strategy aligns with the agreed cyber risk appetite (Action A3), meets relevant regulatory obligations, and accounts for current or expected changes (Action A5).
levels: Board has no assurance the strategy reflects risk appetite, regulations, or change.
Informal alignment claimed; documentation and testing are weak.
Documented alignment exists; coverage and responsiveness are limited.
Strategy is clearly aligned to appetite and regulations and updates with change.
Alignment is embedded and proactive, with early adaptation to new risks and rules.
followOn: Require an alignment statement and gap list with actions to meet appetite and regulatory duties.
Request written mapping of strategy items to appetite thresholds and regulatory requirements; set change checkpoints.
Require key indicators linked to appetite and compliance and an update cycle tied to change triggers.
Introduce scenario testing and exceptions reporting with corrective actions and independent assurance.
Schedule horizon scans and ensure investment decisions show impact on appetite and compliance posture.

actions.title: Allocate resources effectively to manage cyber risks
actions.notes: Gain assurance that resources are allocated effectively to manage the agreed cyber risks (Action A3 and A5).
levels: Not aware of any incident response plan.
Board discusses plan, but it isn't documented.
Aware of draft plan on paper, but no completion date.
Board has seen plan, but not periodically reviewed.
Board is assured plan is regularly reviewed as required.
followOn: Request confirmation from management on whether an incident plan exists and initiate development.
Direct management to draft a formal plan with defined roles and steps and set a review timeline.
Require completion and approval of the plan by a specific date, including escalation and communication paths.
Establish a review cycle, request evidence of testing, and ensure integration with continuity plans.
Maintain regular review and benchmarking against standards; expand scope to suppliers and third parties.

actions.title: Gain assurance that the cyber strategy is delivered and effective
actions.notes: Gain assurance that the cyber strategy is being delivered effectively and is achieving the intended outcomes.
levels: Board has no assurance on delivery or outcomes of the cyber strategy.
Ad-hoc updates exist; outcomes and evidence are unclear.
Structured reporting exists; link to risk reduction is partial.
Delivery is on plan, with clear evidence of outcomes and risk reduction.
Delivery is predictable, value-focused, and continuously improved.
followOn: Require a delivery plan with milestones, owners, due dates and simple outcome measures.
Mandate traffic-light status and exceptions reporting for off-track items.
Tie each initiative to specific risk indicators and benefits realisation tracking.
Hold quarterly deep-dives on major workstreams and require post-implementation reviews.
Maintain independent assurance over delivery governance and benchmark outcomes with peers.

actions.title: Promote a positive cyber security culture
actions.notes: Promote a cyber security culture that encourages positive behaviours and accountability across all levels. This should be aligned with the organisation’s strategy (Action B1).
levels: Board has no assurance that a cyber security culture exists or supports the business strategy.
Cyber culture is informally encouraged, but not documented or measured.
Policies exist; limited assurance on adoption and accountability.
Cyber culture is actively promoted, with training and accountability measures in place.
Cyber culture is embedded and aligned with business strategy; behaviours are measured and improved continuously.
followOn: Ask management whether cyber culture is addressed in policies or training and require a board statement.
Require a formal policy promoting cyber responsibility and examples of communications reinforcing behaviour.
Request metrics on training and evidence of enforcement; embed culture into onboarding and reviews.
Introduce culture KPIs and annual reviews, plus independent checks to validate culture.
Maintain regular culture assessments and link indicators to strategic outcomes and reporting.

actions.title: Establish clear cyber security policies that support positive behaviours
actions.notes: Gain assurance that there are clear policies that support a positive cyber security culture.
levels: Board has no assurance that cyber security policies exist or support positive behaviours.
Policies exist informally or in draft, but not approved or communicated.
Policies are approved and communicated, but adoption and enforcement are unclear.
Policies are embedded in processes, with monitoring and accountability in place.
Policies are fully integrated, regularly updated, and drive continuous improvement.
followOn: Ask management to confirm whether policies exist and require creation of basic behaviour-focused policies.
Require formal approval, a communication plan, and evidence of distribution.
Request metrics on acknowledgements and enforcement and embed policies into performance processes.
Introduce KPIs on compliance and require annual policy reviews and independent checks.
Benchmark policies against standards and include policy indicators in board dashboards and reports.

actions.title: Improve board cyber literacy and secure behaviours
actions.notes: Undertake training to improve your own cyber literacy and take responsibility for the security of the data and digital assets that you use.
levels: Board doesn't receive cyber training or take personal responsibility for secure behaviours.
Board completes basic training ad-hoc; personal responsibility is not documented or tracked.
Training is documented and completed, with limited assurance over secure board behaviours.
Directors are cyber-literate, with consistent secure behaviours and periodic refreshers.
Cyber literacy and secure behaviours are embedded, regularly updated, and role-modelled by the board.
followOn: Introduce a training schedule and expectations for secure board practices.
Set a formal training plan and a simple secure practices policy for directors with reporting.
Request evidence of secure practices and periodic phishing awareness exercises.
Introduce board KPIs and scenario briefings; commission annual checks of board practices.
Maintain workshops with external experts and include cyber literacy in board evaluations.

actions.title: Assure staff cyber training, education and awareness
actions.notes: Gain assurance, using suitable metrics, that the organisation has an effective cyber security training, education and awareness programme.
levels: Board has no assurance that staff receive cyber training or awareness activities.
Training occurs ad-hoc, with no metrics or assurance on coverage or effectiveness.
Training is documented and tracked, but effectiveness is unclear.
Training and awareness are regular, measured, and linked to behaviour change.
Training and awareness are embedded, proactive, and continuously improved.
followOn: Ask management to confirm any training exists and require a basic plan for all staff.
Require a formal training schedule and participation reporting.
Request outcome metrics beyond completion and a plan to improve effectiveness.
Introduce KPIs on behaviour change and require annual effectiveness reviews and assurance.
Benchmark training against standards and include training effectiveness in dashboards.

actions.title: Incident response and recovery plan
actions.notes: Gain assurance that the organisation has a plan to respond to and recover from a cyber incident impacting business critical technology processes, information and services.
levels: Board has no assurance that an incident response and recovery plan exists.
A plan exists informally or in draft, but not approved or tested.
Plan is approved and documented, but limited assurance on readiness.
Plan is tested regularly, with clear roles and improvement actions.
Incident response and recovery are embedded, proactive, and aligned to business priorities.
followOn: Ask management whether a plan exists and mandate development for critical systems.
Require formal approval, clear ownership, and communication of the plan.
Request tabletop exercises and integration with business continuity plans.
Introduce KPIs (e.g. time to detect/recover) and require annual scenario exercises.
Benchmark against best practice and include readiness indicators in board dashboards.

actions.notes: Gain assurance that there is at least annual exercising of the plan involving relevant internal and external stakeholders and that lessons from the exercise are reflected in the incident plan (Action D1) and risk assessments (Action A5).
actions.title: Exercising the incident plan and learning lessons
levels: Board has no assurance that the incident plan is tested or improved.
Exercises occur informally, with limited scope and no lessons captured.
Annual exercises are documented, but follow-up improvements are inconsistent.
Exercises are regular, structured, and drive continuous improvement.
Testing and improvement are embedded, with proactive scenario planning.
followOn: Ask whether any exercises have been done and require an annual testing schedule.
Mandate formal documentation of exercises and lessons learned updates to the plan.
Require a tracking log for improvement actions and integration into risk assessments.
Introduce KPIs on implementation of lessons and require board observation of exercises.
Maintain scenario planning workshops and benchmark exercise design and outcomes.

actions.title: Board role and regulatory obligations during incidents
actions.notes: In the event of an incident, take responsibility for individual regulatory obligations, such as reporting, and support the organisation in critical decision making and external communications.
levels: Board has no clarity on its regulatory obligations or role during an incident.
Board has basic awareness, but roles and escalation paths are unclear.
Board roles are documented, but limited assurance on readiness.
Board is prepared and practiced for its regulatory and decision-making role.
Board involvement is embedded and proactive, supporting resilience and compliance.
followOn: Request a plain-English briefing on board obligations and reporting requirements.
Require a board incident response guide and scenario-based training.
Schedule annual board participation in exercises and create communication templates.
Introduce KPIs on board readiness and require post-exercise reviews.
Maintain annual scenario workshops and include readiness indicators in dashboards.

actions.title: Post-incident reviews and learning
actions.notes: Gain assurance that a post incident review process is in place to incorporate lessons learned into future risk assessments (Action A5), response and recovery plans (Action D1) and exercising (Action D2).
levels: Board has no assurance that lessons from incidents are reviewed or applied.
Reviews occur informally, with limited documentation or follow-up.
Reviews are documented, but integration into plans and risk assessments is inconsistent.
Post-incident reviews drive improvements in plans and risk management.
Learning and improvement are embedded and proactive, shaping future resilience.
followOn: Ask whether post-incident reviews are done and require a formal process and reporting.
Mandate written reports with root cause and actions and tracking of improvements.
Require logs of lessons and evidence of updates to plans and risk registers.
Introduce KPIs on implementation of lessons and annual summaries of improvements.
Benchmark lessons-learned practices and include learning indicators in governance reports.

actions.title: Cyber governance structure and roles
actions.notes: Establish a cyber governance structure which is embedded within the wider governance structure of the organisation. This should include clear definition of roles and responsibilities, including ownership of cyber at executive and non-executive director level.
levels: Board has no assurance of a defined cyber governance structure or roles.
Governance is informal or draft, with unclear responsibilities and escalation.
Governance is documented and approved; embedding and effectiveness are limited.
Cyber governance is embedded with clear roles, decisions, and reporting.
Governance is mature, proactive, and integrated with overall corporate governance.
followOn: Require a cyber governance charter and named executive/board roles.
Mandate formal approval of the governance model and RACI with escalation routes.
Request attendance and action logs; link governance decisions to risk and strategy.
Introduce KPIs on escalation timeliness and action closure; require annual effectiveness reviews.
Maintain cross-committee alignment and benchmark governance against peers; refresh charters annually.

actions.title: Formal reporting, metrics and tolerances
actions.notes: Require formal reporting on at least a quarterly basis, set suitable metrics to track, and agree tolerances for each. These should be aligned to the cyber strategy (Action B1) and based on the agreed cyber risk appetite (Action A3).
levels: Board doesn't receive any formal cyber reporting or metrics.
Reporting is ad-hoc with limited metrics and no agreed tolerances.
Quarterly reporting with documented metrics exists; alignment and escalation are partial.
Reporting is regular, aligned, with clear tolerances and actions.
Metrics and reporting are embedded, decision-ready, and continuously improved.
followOn: Require quarterly reporting with a simple metric set and thresholds tied to appetite.
Mandate a standard template with definitions and tolerances for key metrics.
Align metrics to business outcomes and require exceptions reporting and spot checks.
Introduce trend analysis and quarterly data quality attestations; review the metric set periodically.
Refresh metrics annually against strategy and benchmarks; automate where possible.

actions.title: Two-way dialogue with senior executives
actions.notes: Establish regular two-way dialogue with relevant senior executives, including but not limited to, the chief information security officer (or equivalent).
levels: Board has no structured dialogue with relevant senior executives on cyber.
Dialogue is infrequent and informal; expectations are unclear.
Regular dialogue exists; quality and follow-through are mixed.
Two-way dialogue is embedded and drives decisions and accountability.
Dialogue is proactive, strategic, and supports continuous improvement.
followOn: Schedule regular sessions with the senior cyber lead and ask for plain-English briefings.
Set a cadence and agenda for two-way sessions with action logs.
Ask for non-technical summaries with options and commission feedback to improve sessions.
Introduce KPIs on closure of agreed actions and hold deep-dives on major topics.
Maintain annual joint workshops and review cyber oversight in board evaluations.

actions.title: Audit and assurance over cyber
actions.notes: Gain assurance that cyber security considerations (including the actions in this code) are integrated and consistent with existing internal and external audit and assurance mechanisms.
levels: Board has no assurance that cyber is covered by audit or assurance mechanisms.
Cyber appears in isolated audits; scope and consistency are unclear.
Cyber is included in plans, but coverage and follow-through are mixed.
Audit and assurance are integrated, risk-based, with timely remediation.
Assurance is embedded, proactive, and drives continuous improvement.
followOn: Direct internal audit to include cyber governance and controls and summarise external assurance.
Require a risk-based audit plan mapped to top cyber risks and tracked actions.
Set coverage targets for critical areas and require periodic status reports and re-tests.
Introduce KPIs on closing high-risk findings and thematic reviews across audits.
Benchmark assurance scope and align outcomes with strategy refresh and risk appetite updates.

actions.title: Executive awareness of regulations and best practice
actions.notes: Gain assurance that senior executives are aware of relevant regulatory obligations, as well as best practice contained within other Codes of Practice.
levels: Board has no assurance that executives know relevant regulations or best practice codes.
Awareness is informal, with no evidence of application to the business.
Executives are briefed and acknowledge obligations; adoption is partial.
Obligations and best practices are understood, implemented, and monitored.
Awareness and adoption are embedded and proactive, supporting compliance and trust.
followOn: Request a register of relevant regulations and codes and executive briefings on obligations.
Require mapping from obligations to policies and controls and compliance sign-off.
Ask for a gap analysis with time-bound actions and quarterly updates.
Introduce KPIs on coverage of obligations and require independent assurance in critical areas.
Maintain horizon scanning and benchmark adoption of best practices; include readiness indicators in reports.
